availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal licence. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.head: ¶ The valuacyō of golde and syluer made ī ye yere. M.C.CCC.lxxxxix. holde ī the marke vnce englice quart troye. dewes and aes The maner for to weight wyth pēnes and graynes and herein is sett ye fygures of ye spaynysh and Poortyngalysh docates whiche is now.

figure.figDesc: face and reverse of coin with inscription
figure.head: ¶ The golde fleys

figure.figDesc: face and reverse of coin with inscription
figure.head: The phūs gyldon

figure.figDesc: face and reverse of coin with inscription
figure.head: ¶ The siluer flyes

figure.figDesc: face and reverse of coin with inscription
figure.head: ¶ The dowble styuer

figure.figDesc: face and reverse of coin with inscription
figure.head: ¶ The syngyle styuere

div.p: ¶ For that euery oon of what state or condycion he be shall the better & sewerlyer haue the right valure off his golde light or other forbodē and sett for bolyon so hath men sett here and ordeyned the ryght valure as nye as may be doon of ye marke vnces englisses quats troyes deweses & and aesses of dyuersys soort{is} of pecis of golde Wher men cōmonly fynde moost of whiche valew by good deliberacion of counsell auaunsed and is chaūged in the moueth of december Anno lxxxxix

list.head: Item nota
list.item: Item oon troyes poūde holde ij marke oon marke holde viij vnces.
the half englice holde xvi aesses

div.p: Sythen ye furst erche duke of ostrijck duke of bourgoō of brabāt &c{is}.
Yerle of flaundres of habsbourth tyrol of artoys of holande sealande namen &c{is}

Ys ordeyned that the money of golde and siluer here after folowȳg shal haue course with ī aɫɫ his landes and there lightnes the pryse wretē by aft folowyng holding in of the ordynaūce not long made and published vpō ye xxv day of december ī ye yere M.CCCC.lxxxix

Whiche money of golde may be weighed ij aesses light thā ther right weight vpō euy pese weɫɫ to vnderstande yt ye half crowne quateirs of nobylles & od of liekenes lytiɫɫ pecis of gold shal not be more thā oon aes lighter may be thā towheer weight aft hold in of ther ordinaūces abowe wreten & yt vpō ye boetes & paynes takē ī ye ordinaūce published ī ye yere as aboue

table.head: ¶ Fyrst the goldyng fleys that men hath mynted and now shaɫɫ myntte weighyng the marke

table.head: The valuacyon of ye siluer money yt of now forthe aen shal haue course & goe & noon other vpon ye boete as abouesayd

row.cell: The doobbeɫɫ wt crowe gryfōnes & of lieke yt wt ye towe helmes and that wyth ye crownes.
The halfes & quatts after te rate
The doobbeɫɫ with ye ij lyons bourgoon
the syngeɫɫ of them after the rate.
the sȳgeɫɫ & q̄ts aft the rate.

The heedes and lyeke of money of sauoye
The frenche blankes hawyng abowte the crosse towe lylyes & ij crownes

figure.figDesc: face and reverse of coin

div.p:
¶ Other frenche blankes that been named dysayns hauyng betwyn ye crosse. iiij lylyes without crownes xl. met{is} flxg{is}
face and reverse of coin

¶ Itē the grootes half & q̄ts mynted within our myntes & noon od shaɫɫ goe. hauyng as they do now
¶ Itē here folowith how many englisses ʐ englysses q̄ts troyes dewesses & aesses euery pese off golde must weight
Fyrst ye goldȳg fleys liiij. ʐ. In the marke ij. englice ʐ. i. q̄t. i troye oon dewes.
The gret ryaeɫɫ off ostrijc xvi ʐ ī ye mar ix englice ʐ i troie i dewes hard
The ynglishe nobeɫɫ wt the roose. xxxij. in the marke v englice
The halfes & quartiers after ye rate
the herryc{is} nobyɫɫ xxxvij in ye mar. iiij. englice i q̄t dewes i troye i ʐ aes
The flemyse nobyɫɫ xxxvi ī ye mar iiij englice i q̄t i troye i dewes & i ʐ aes
the halfes of thē after ye rate & quart
The aūgeɫɫ of ynglād lxviij. ī ye mar. iij englice i quartier i dewes & i aes.
the half of the same after the rate
The golde lyoon lx in the mark ij englice ʐ i. troye i dewes & oon aes
ye towe {per}tes of ye lyoō. lxxxxviij ʐ ī ye m̄
i ʐ. englice i quartier & i dewes
The thirde of ye same. C. lxxvij ī ye m̄
ʐ englice i quartier i troye and i aes.
The golde rider lxx in ye mark ij englice i quartier i dewes scaers
The crown with ye sonne lieke ye rpd
the halfes of thē C xl in the marke i englice i troye. and oon aes
The dokate of hongray lxix. ī ye mar ij englice i quart i dewes i aes scaers
The docate of ytalye the salute. the wilhelm{is} shilde ye olde frēche crowne been of lxxij in the marke ij englice i troye i dewes i aes & i ʐ aed
the half of them after the rate.
The towe {per}tis of ye salute C viij. ī ye m̄
oon englice oon half englice scaers
The scuyt ye iohēs shilde lxxiij ī ye mar ij englice i troye i dewes i aes half
The phūs gyldon yt mē now mynte the bourgounsh andreys gyldon.
the geldres ryd lxxiiij. in ye mark ij englice i troye i aes and oon ʐ aes
The vtrechsh gyldon dauid.
The phūs clinckaert
the louēsh pet of lxvi ī ye marke ij englice I. troye scaers
The frederic{is} & beyers gildō. lxxviij in the marke. weighing. ij. englice. i. dewes scaers
The arnold{is} gyldō. lxxxxij. ī ye mark weighith. i englice ʐ. & oon. quatier
The postolaet wyth the harmes off bourboon and wt the hownud. lxxxi ī ye mark. weight ij ēglite skaes
The golde coruorsters gyldōs. lxxv ī the marke. ij englice. I troye. & oon. ʐ aes
¶ Item here after folowith ye maner for ye weyghyng wt ye penni weight
¶ Item oon penny is xxiiij. grayen & xxviij. grayē ʐ maketh oon englice

row.cell: the thirde parte of ye same.
The postelaet wyth the harmes off bourboon and wyth the hownde.

div.p: ¶ Item the penny fyne of golde ys worthe. xiiij stouers ʐ amyte that is. ij. s̄ iiij d and ʐ amyte flemyse g{is}.
The grayen of fyne golde is worthe xxviij. mytis flemyse g{is}

¶ This after folowyng been the peces of golde that of late beē ordeyned of behalf off my souerayn lorde. the Ercheduke of Oostrijck of Brabant &c{is}. that now fortheon haue course & goe and shalbe take aboue the valuacyon made in the ordynaūce and publessed ī ye yere lxxxxix. last passed

row.cell: Fyrst the Castilyaen of fyne golde weighyng liij ʐ. ī ye mark
The dobbeɫɫ docaet of Spayen. weighyng xxxv. ī ye mark
The docaet of ye same of lxx ī ye mark. lieke ye docaet of hōgherey

figure.figDesc: face and reverse of coin
figure.head: The Cruysades

row.cell: The docaet mynted Portingale. named cruysades of .lxx. in ye mark
been valuered .vi. s. vi. d g{is}

div.p:
¶ This is the englice weight of th •…
se foresaid pecis of golde of spayē an •… portyngale

row.cell: The castilian of fyne golde. liij. ʐ in 〈…〉 mark.
ij. englice ʐ. i. quartier. i troye i. dewes oon aes ʐ.
The doobbeɫɫ docaet of Spayen. xxxv. in the marke
iiij englice ʐ. and oon troye.
The docaet of the same. lxx. in the mar.
ij eng. i. quart. i▪ dewes scaers
The cruyssade off Portyngale of lxx. in the marke
ij. englic i. q̄ti. dewes scaers.

table.head: ¶ This is yt penny weight of ye foresaid spaynish & portȳgalysh peces of fyne golde
